messageBody:
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Hi,

Am Mittwoch, 2. April 2003 04:44 schrieb Vladimir R. Bossicard:
> > But it seems to me that I don't need necessarily JUnit test cases or
> > suites if I use the new assert statement in the code I write.
>
> I would use the JDK1.4 assert method and not the JUnit methods:
>
> - the JDK assert methods can be disabled at runtime
a) That's not an advantage over JUnit because TestCases aren't even loaded at
runtime, you can even hold them in a seperate jar archive.

> - you don't have to ship JUnit with your application
See a) and that's not really a problem.

Depends on the semantics:
- - Java assert for *internal* pre/post-conditions/invariants
- - JUnit Assertions for *interface* pre/post-conditions, states


> > And I read that it is extremely time consuming to create test cases
> > for all possible cases.
>
> Since it's impossible to test all possible cases, it's true that writing
> tests for all these cases is very consuming.
There's still something like the 80/20-rule. Writing test cases to cover 80%
takes 20% of the time. So concentrate on these and on finding the most
valuable of those other 20% left.

But still it's less time consuming than repeatedly debugging sessions.
